title: Hawks‚Äô 2 best trade upgrade options using Kristaps Porzingis‚Äô $30.7 million expiring contract
description: Kristaps Porzingis hasn't been as impactful for the Hawks as they'd hoped due to injury. Will they change course and trade him away?
fullText:
Hawks‚Äô 2 best trade upgrade options using Kristaps Porzingis‚Äô $30.7 million expiring contract appeared first on ClutchPoints. 

The Atlanta Hawks are nowhere near where they envisioned they would be heading into the 2025-26 campaign. This past offseason, they were very aggressive, bringing in Kristaps Porzingis and Nickeil Alexander-Walker via trade and free agency, respectively, to try and make the leap in the wide-open Eastern Conference. But instead of taking the leap, they‚Äôve stayed very much mediocre as they head into Christmas Day with a 15-16 record amid their current four-game losing skid.

There is plenty of talent on the Hawks‚Äô roster, but somehow, they haven‚Äôt put it together quite yet this season. Their offseason additions, which were supposed to elevate Atlanta defensively, haven‚Äôt made the impact they were expected to.

On the season, they rank 18th in defensive rating, allowing 115.6 points per 100 possessions, and since Trae Young returned from injury on the 18th of December, they‚Äôve allowed 125.8 points per 100 ‚Äî good for third-worst in the NBA during that span.

Suffice to say, the Hawks may be feeling a sense of urgency to be aggressive on the trade market considering their present circumstances. Porzingis is dealing with further complications brought forth by his Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS), leaving Atlanta with just Onyeka Okongwu at center.

If Atlanta is indeed feeling the heat, desperation could very well push them to trade Porzingis away to acquire another center. The uncertainty surrounding the Latvian big man may become untenable for a Hawks side that wants to be one of the best teams in the East, and with his contract set to expire at the end of this current campaign, he will be an piece to take on for teams looking to free up salary.

With that said, here are three trade options the Hawks could pursue amid Porzingis‚Äô bout with injury.

Hawks acquire: Myles Turner, Andre Jackson Jr.

Bucks acquire: Kristaps Porzingis, 2026 SAS first-round pick

The Hawks‚Äô vision was clear when they acquired Porzingis in the trade that saw them give up Terance Mann, Georges Niang, and a 2025 first-round pick (Drake Powell). With Clint Capela departing in free agency, a spot opened up in their center rotation. Porzingis emerged as a perfect fit alongside Jalen Johnson in the frontcourt; Johnson is a slasher who can finish well on the interior, while Porzingis loves letting it fly from beyond the arc. And with Young handling the offense, Atlanta was sure to feast.

Porzingis also provides more rim protection than Okongwu thanks to his length (he stands at 7‚Äô2‚Ä≥ with a 7‚Äô6‚Ä≥ wingspan), and Atlanta needed a tone-setter on the defensive end considering how average they‚Äôve been on that end of the floor over the past few seasons.

Alas, rolling the dice on Porzingis was always going to be a risk. He‚Äôs already been injury-prone enough over his entire career, but a mystery illness kept him out of the Boston Celtics‚Äô lineup way too often for their liking during last season‚Äôs playoffs and sapped him of productivity whenever he was on the court.

That mystery illness was diagnosed later on as POTS, and now, Porzingis is dealing with its effects and is unable to suit up on the basketball court. As much as he would want to produce for the Hawks (and he‚Äôs been very productive when healthy), his body is not allowing him to ‚Äî forcing Atlanta into making some very tough decisions.

The player archetype the Hawks want at center is very clear. They want a floor-spacer who can block shots consistently. And as luck would have it, a player of that ilk may become available on the trade market in Myles Turner.

Turner, who signed a four-year, $108.9 million contract with the Milwaukee Bucks this past offseason, has struggled in his first season away from Indianapolis. His numbers are down across the board, and considering the total cost the Bucks paid to sign him (waiving and stretching Damian Lillard‚Äôs contract), he has played at a level way below expectations, not at all coming close to being the piece Milwaukee needed to make a convincing case for Giannis Antetokounmpo to pledge his future to the city.

It‚Äôs going to be a tough pill for the Bucks to swallow that their signing of Turner was a mistake, but they can rectify that by trading him away for Porzingis‚Äô expiring contract while getting a first-round pick for their troubles.

Now, the Hawks owe the San Antonio Spurs a pick swap next year courtesy of the Dejounte Murray trade. That pick of theirs will most likely land in the late first round. To that end, Atlanta should be very comfortable trading away a late-first round pick for a 3-and-D center with plenty of experience doing damage alongside a talented playmaker.

The Bucks, meanwhile, get a chance to clean the books and try again in free agency next year. They have a 12-18 record on the season, and with Antetokounmpo still not on the comeback trail, it could make sense for them to do this and get a first-round pick in return.

Hawks acquire: Ivica Zubac, Bogdan Bogdanovic

Clippers acquire: Kristaps Porzingis, 2026 ATL first-round pick (SAS own swap rights with ATL), 2027 ATL first-round pick swap (LAC receives more favorable of less favorable pick between ATL and NOP and less favorable of LAC/DEN/OKC picks), 2028 ATL first-round pick, 2029 ATL first-round pick swap

Trading away two first-round picks and two pick swaps for Ivica Zubac doesn‚Äôt seem very smart for the Hawks to do. For starters, Zubac is currently out with an ankle sprain and is going to be on the mend for multiple weeks. Moreover, it‚Äôs not like Atlanta is a piece away from winning a title; they‚Äôre 15-16 at the moment and are very much struggling.

But Zubac solves a lot of the Hawks‚Äô problems. For starters, Zubac has been known to anchor an elite defense in the past for the Clippers. Sure, LA‚Äôs defense has been very bad this year, but that can be attributed as much to their woeful perimeter defense as it can be to any form of decline from the 28-year-old center.

Zubac is also a more traditional pick-and-roll dance partner for Young, someone who can feast off of dimes from the Hawks‚Äô star point guard. Capela was a lob threat who can protect the rim; Zubac is similar in that respect, but he‚Äôs different in that he has better touch from the interior and can even be given the ball in the post ‚Äî his hook shot is near-automatic from point-blank range.

The Hawks, for giving the Clippers pick swap options and unprotected first-round picks for Zubac, will also be getting a familiar face back in Bogdan Bogdanovic. Bogdanovic adds another ballhandler and shooter for Atlanta off the bench, and his contract will be expiring in 2026 so he won‚Äôt be on the books for long.

The Clippers will then be getting an opportunity to begin their process of starting over, arming themselves with more future draft picks. They have been also playing noticeably better as of late; perhaps having a stretch five would be the way to go for them moving forward. To that end, if Porzingis were ever to be healthy, he could be a huge help for LA in their quest to at least rescue a play-in tournament spot after a ghastly start to the 2025-26 campaign.

This, however, is an unlikely swing for the Hawks to make. Young is presumably going to be entering free agency at season‚Äôs end (he has a player option for the 2026-27 campaign worth $48.97 million), which clouds Atlanta‚Äôs future with so much uncertainty. But this could be a worthwhile swing if they were truly hellbent on making it work with Young at the controls.

title: Warriors‚Äô Stephen Curry rocking Klay Thompson‚Äôs signature shoes vs. Mavs on Christmas
description: Warriors All-Star Stephen Curry wore former teammate in Mavericks' Klay Thompson's signature shoes on Christmas Day.
fullText:
Warriors‚Äô Stephen Curry rocking Klay Thompson‚Äôs signature shoes vs. Mavs on Christmas appeared first on ClutchPoints. 

Golden State Warriors All-Star Stephen Curry reached his 26,000-point career milestone in a 126-116 Christmas Day win against the Dallas Mavericks, and did it while wearing Klay Thompson‚Äôs signature shoes. Curry spent 13 seasons as one half of the infamous ‚ÄúSplash Brothers‚Äù duo, alongside Thompson. The 3-point chucking pair helped lead the Warriors to four championships in seven seasons.

Curry rocking Thompson‚Äôs signature shoes is a fitting way to pay homage to his former teammate, while playing against him, as The Dallas Morning News‚Äô Mike Curtis noted.

‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt notice this until now, but sneaker free agent Stephen Curry is wearing Klay Thompson‚Äôs shoes by ANTA,‚Äù Curtis reported.

Didn‚Äôt notice this until now, but sneaker free agent Stephen Curry is wearing Klay Thompson‚Äôs shoes by ANTA. pic.twitter.com/Ih0F69O5wn

‚Äî Mike Curtis (@MikeACurtis2) December 25, 2025

Curry became the 22nd player in NBA history to score 26,000+ points in his career in the third quarter of the Warriors‚Äô 10-point win against the Mavs.

26,000 CAREER POINTS FOR STEPH CURRY!

The 22nd player in NBA history to reach that mark ü§© pic.twitter.com/JBX4zU0UiA

Curry finished with 23 points on 6-of-18 shooting and a perfect 9-for-9 from the free-throw line. He also finished with four assists and three rebounds. Klay Thompson scored seven points on 3-of-8 attempts off the bench, two rebounds, two assists, one steal, and one block for the Mavs.

Mavericks rookie Cooper Flagg impressed Warriors All-Star Stephen Curry with his game-high 27-point performance in Thursday‚Äôs Christmas Day matchup. Flagg, who has participated in Curry‚Äôs basketball camp before entering the NBA, went 13-of-21 from the floor and finished with six rebounds, five assists, and one block in his first matchup against Steph and the Warriors.

After the game, in his walk-off interview, Curry discussed what he sees in Flagg‚Äôs future, per NBA on ESPN‚Äôs X (formerly Twitter).

‚ÄúJust a true hooper. Competitor. You forget how young he is ‚Äî just his presence out there on the court,‚Äù Curry said. ‚ÄúSo, the future is bright. I‚Äôm glad he got this experience in his first year to understand what the bright lights feel like. The league is in good hands.‚Äù

"Just a true hooper. Competitor. ‚Ä¶ The league is in good hands."

Steph Curry had high praise for Cooper Flagg after their matchup ü§ù pic.twitter.com/sf4t8EnzUc

‚Äî NBA on ESPN (@ESPNNBA) December 26, 2025

The Warriors have won three consecutive games.

title: Magic trade proposal to Bulls adds Coby White to talented young core
description: Will the Magic emerge as the winner in the Coby White sweepstakes with trade rumors involving the Bulls guard growing louder and louder?
fullText:
Magic trade proposal to Bulls adds Coby White to talented young core appeared first on ClutchPoints. 

The Orlando Magic made it clear this past offseason that they were looking forward to taking the next step in their road to contention. They traded away a king‚Äôs ransom of future draft picks to bring in Desmond Bane, hoping that he‚Äôll be the shooter the team has sorely needed amid their struggles on the offensive end over the past few seasons.

But it‚Äôs become evident that Orlando needs more than just Bane to take advantage of their opportunity in the wide-open Eastern Conference. The injury bug has not been kind once more to the Magic, as the likes of Paolo Banchero, Franz Wagner, and Jalen Suggs ‚Äî their three franchise guys ‚Äî have all missed time. In fact, Wagner is out for a few more weeks at the minimum, while Suggs has been dealing with a hip injury over the past few weeks.

This may push the Magic to pull off a trade to bolster the team further, and they have reportedly been linked to a potential trade for Chicago Bulls guard Coby White. White is in the final year of his contract, and with Chicago treading on the line of mediocrity yet again, this could be the year where they decide to cash out on White as a trade asset.

However, the Bane trade has depleted Orlando‚Äôs trade assets, making them unfavored in any trade scenario for White. Nonetheless, here is a trade proposal that could convince Chicago to give them their explosive scoring guard.

Magic acquire: Coby White, Jevon Carter

Bulls acquire: Jonathan Isaac, Jett Howard, 2026 DET/MIL second-round pick, 2027 ORL second-round pick, 2028 ORL second-round pick

The Magic have loved Jonathan Isaac since day one, and it‚Äôs not hard to see why. Isaac, when healthy, is one of the best defensive players in the NBA. He‚Äôs capable of guarding everyone from one to five, and that description isn‚Äôt hyperbole. He can indeed slide his feet even against quicker guards, and he can protect the rim and even stand toe to toe with post-up brutes.

But Isaac has lost so much developmental steam throughout his career due to injuries, and the Magic team seems to have outgrown him already. And Orlando, of all teams, would know just how much care there must be to prevent Isaac from suffering another long-term injury. Fans have to remember that Isaac missed two full seasons (2020-21 and 2021-22 seasons) and played just 11 games during the 2022-23 campaign.

Nonetheless, the Magic know how elite he is on defense, even though he cannot log heavy minutes anymore due to his injury history. Thus, inking him to a five-year, $84 million contract made sense at the time (mid-2024).

However, in today‚Äôs CBA landscape, the bill comes due quite quickly for teams on the rise. Suggs, the 2021 draftee, was signed to a five-year, $150.5 million deal. Wagner, another 2021 draftee, signed a stunning supermax contract over five years that could be worth as much as $270 million. And then there‚Äôs Banchero, the first overall pick of 2022. He‚Äôs the Magic‚Äôs franchise player, so doing anything other than inking him to a five-year, $239 million deal would have been asinine.

Adding Bane, who signed a five-year, $207 million deal with the Memphis Grizzlies back in 2023, has further complicated cap matters for the Magic. Those four players alone will be making a combined estimate of around $156 million.

Time is ticking on the Magic, and Isaac appears likely to give way in a cap-saving maneuver. To that end, Orlando may as well get a quality player in return and target White, someone who can provide a scoring punch from the perimeter to aid the cause for them amid Wagner and Suggs‚Äô injuries.

It is unlikely that White stays in Orlando long-term considering the Magic‚Äôs clogged cap sheet situation, but ClutchPoints NBA insider Brett Siegel did mention that the Magic ‚Äúwould be willing to move on from Jonathan Isaac and second-round assets to add scoring depth‚Äù. White would be nothing more than a rental, but if Orlando were to trade him eventually anyway, they shouldn‚Äôt just do so for the sake of clearing future cap obligations.

The Magic have been starting Anthony Black and Tyus Jones in the backcourt amid Wagner and Suggs‚Äô injuries. Black has been good all year and has been making a third-year leap, but Jones, at this point, is better-suited to being a backup point guard. His inconsistency can be very infuriating, and his plus-minus numbers have been bad all year. According to PBP Stats, the Magic‚Äôs net rating this season is worse by 13 points whenever Jones is on the floor.

That is not exactly an ideal situation for a Magic team that‚Äôs looking to compete for a title this year. White is not going to be the piece that takes them over the top, but he‚Äôs an incredible depth piece to have, an excellent sixth man for when Orlando gets back its core players, and acquiring his Bird rights means that they at least open themselves up to the possibility of retaining White as a trade asset.

As for the Bulls, this trade is an admission that their current core is not good enough and that White is a legitimate flight risk considering that he‚Äôs in the final year of his contract. Chicago has hovered in and around the play-in spots over the past few seasons, and losing yet another quality piece for nothing is not going to aid their cause in their ongoing rebuild.

Alas, this return won‚Äôt (and shouldn‚Äôt) be enough for the Bulls. They will at least want one first-round pick in any White trade, especially when White is just 25 years of age and has proven himself to be one of the best scoring machines in the NBA, having tallied 21.4 points per game thus far this season.

Isaac could be a good defensive piece for a team starved of them, Jett Howard could become something, a post-hype breakout wing, while three second-round picks are nothing to scoff at. But in the end, the Magic simply may not have enough assets to entice the Bulls to trade White to Orlando. That doesn‚Äôt mean that they shouldn‚Äôt try anymore.

title: ROAD TO GLORY: The journey of Wall‚Äôs 2025 state championship win
description: SAN ANGELO, Texas (Concho Valley Homepage) ‚Äî Click the video above to relive the Wall Hawks‚Äô road to the 2025 state championship. If there‚Äôs one team in the Concho Valley enjoying its 2025 holiday season, it‚Äôs the Wall Hawks. The school brought home its first-ever football state title one week ago, but this year‚Äôs championship [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
SAN ANGELO, Texas (Concho Valley Homepage) ‚Äî Click the video above to relive the Wall Hawks‚Äô road to the 2025 state championship.

If there‚Äôs one team in the Concho Valley enjoying its 2025 holiday season, it‚Äôs the Wall Hawks. The school brought home its first-ever football state title one week ago, but this year‚Äôs championship run didn‚Äôt come as a surprise to many people.

KLST Sports Director Charles Bryce had a vision. During KLST and KSAN‚Äôs 2025 High School Football Preview Show on Aug 20, he said ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt wait to see some of these teams that have a really good shot at winning a state championship. Let‚Äôs see who can bring one home to the Concho Valley this year.‚Äù

Bryce‚Äôs preseason analysis aged very well. Four months later, Wall stood tall as the Concho Valley‚Äôs lone state champion. Wall‚Äôs second-year head coach Craig Slaughter also had a vision this season, and his squad‚Äôs road to glory was in the works for years.

‚ÄúIt still probably hasn‚Äôt sunk in, [I‚Äôm] just proud,‚Äù Slaughter said. ‚Äú[I‚Äôve gotten] so many texts from people that have followed our program for a long time. We‚Äôve been chasing it for a long time, we‚Äôve been in the hunt for a long time and that‚Äôs before I got here. This program has been knocking on the door for a while and it‚Äôs awesome to get that done.‚Äù

When Slaughter became head coach in 2024, he guided the Hawks to the Class 3A Division II State Semifinals which resulted in a heartbreaking 42-32 loss to the Gunter Tigers. That loss served as motivation for players and coaches heading into the next season. One year later, Wall got its revenge with a 28-25 state semis win over Gunter.

‚ÄúWe knew how to handle ourselves much better,‚Äù Hawks senior right tackle Will Aldridge said. ‚ÄúOn the sidelines, you could tell we weren‚Äôt out of this game. We still had a lot more football to play, and I think a big part of it was just that maturity level.‚Äù

‚ÄòWe‚Äôre a fourth quarter type of team,‚Äù Hawks senior running back Brady Neal said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre very physical, we‚Äôve got good chemistry. Even though we were down, we knew that just one play could get us back in it.‚Äù

In the ensuing state championship game versus the Newton Eagles, Wall‚Äôs commanding 25-8 halftime lead proved to be just enough to secure the win. The Hawks survived the Eagles‚Äô second-half comeback attempt, which fell one point short as Wall held on to win 25-24.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt give enough credit to our kids,‚Äù coach Slaughter said. ‚ÄúTheir composure is awesome. They just keep playing, and they found themselves a state championship.‚Äù

Wall‚Äôs season-defining theme revolved around talent and depth. The Hawks‚Äô stacked roster featured 23 seniors, giving them the edge over opponents in terms of experience.

‚ÄúOurs wasn‚Äôt just 23 players,‚Äù coach Slaughter said. ‚ÄúThere were 23 leaders, strong kids, and just a talented roster. Some of the kids were waiting in line for reps for us, and it just speaks to the depth of that squad.‚Äù

After many years of knocking on the doorstep, the Wall Hawks can finally call themselves state champions. This 2025 championship team will be remembered for many years to come.

title: Lakers‚Äô Luka Doncic calls out himself, teammates after blowout loss to Rockets
description: Los Angeles Lakers star Luka Doncic made an honest self-review after their loss to the Houston Rockets on Wednesday.
fullText:
Lakers‚Äô Luka Doncic calls out himself, teammates after blowout loss to Rockets appeared first on ClutchPoints. 

Luka Doncic did not have to look far to find someone to blame after the Los Angeles Lakers lost to the Houston Rockets, 119-96, leaving their fans disappointed at Crypto.com Arena on Christmas Day.

The Lakers allowed the Rockets to have a strong start, scoring 37 points in the first quarter. The Purple and Gold never managed to bounce back, suffering their third straight defeat.

After the game, Doncic was an image of frustration. He, however, admitted that he was accountable for their loss.

‚ÄúEveryone has to give better effort, starting with me,‚Äù said the 26-year-old star, as quoted by The Athletic‚Äôs Dan Woike.

Doncic tallied 25 points on 9-of-17 shooting, five rebounds, and seven assists. He also had a game-high six turnovers.

LeBron James added 18 points, five rebounds, and two steals. Austin Reaves, meanwhile, had to be pulled out early in the game after reaggravating his calf injury. He had 12 points in 15 minutes.

Los Angeles allowed Houston to shoot 53% from the field and got outrebounded, 48-25. The Rockets scored 23 points off the 16 turnovers of the Lakers.

The 26-year-old Doncic has said he needs to regain the defensive effort he showed in the first few games of the season. He has been slowed down by injuries as of late, but it shouldn‚Äôt be an excuse for a perennial All-Star to play lackadaisically.

Lakers coach JJ Redick has repeatedly rhapsodized about making a complete effort on both ends, and as Doncic acknowledged, he should be the one setting an example for everyone.

The Lakers fell to 19-10, including 7-5 at home.

title: Top 10 Lowcountry sports stories of 2025
description: MT. PLEASANT, S.C. (WCBD) ‚Äì A lot to celebrate this holiday season as it was another great year for Lowcountry sports. It was tough to dwindle down the top ten stories of 2025 but we did our best.
fullText:
MT. PLEASANT, S.C. (WCBD) ‚Äì A lot to celebrate this holiday season as it was another great year for Lowcountry sports. It was tough to dwindle down the top ten stories of 2025 but we did our best.

Top story #10 ‚Äì 2025 was a banner year for Mt. Pleasants Debbie Antonelli, literally. In January the NC State alum was inducted into the Wolfpack basketball Ring of Honor for her contributions to the sport. On Halloween the town of Mt. Pleasant officially named the gym at town hall in her honor. ‚ÄúThe Deb is a testament to Antonelli‚Äôs work promoting the game and the Special Olympics as she hopes to serve as an inspiration for other young girls like herself with a love of basketball.

Top story #9 ‚Äì Berkeley High School has been around since 1912, in its entire school history the Stags had yet to win a state title in basketball. That all changed one March afternoon in Florence when the Lady Stags defeated Greenwood for the SCHSL 5A D2 championship. Berkeley alum head coach Crystal Peace overwhelmed as her Stags finally reached the mountain top.

Top story #8 ‚Äì In James Island¬†baseball‚Äôs last game in 4A in 2024, they won their third state title in school history. Fast forward to the last day of May as the Trojans were down to their last three outs in extra innings in the decisive game for the 5A D1 crown against Lexington. Collin Anderson drove in the tying run with a ringing double to right center. Later in the bottom of the eighth with Anderson on second, Jake Amman comes through with the biggest knock of his life driving in Anderson as the Trojans go back to back defeating the Wildcats in dramatic fashion. Can I get an Amman?

Top story #7 ‚Äì John McKissick holds the record for the most wins as a high school head football coach in the state, and probably will never be passed. Coach has company in flower town as Pinewood Prep head basketball coach Pat Eidson became the states all time winningest head coach in January. With a 67 ‚Äì 31 win over Palmetto Christian, pat won his 944th game as a head coach. After stops at Easley Christian and Northside Christian, Eidson has been at Pinewood since 1990.

Top story #6 ‚Äì Coastal Carolina baseball was two wins away from their second national title in school history. After winning the Sun Belt regular season and tournament titles, the Chants breezed through the Conway regional before sweeping Auburn down on the plains in the Auburn super regional. Coastal‚Äôs win streak reached a remarkable 26 games in a row when they defeated Louisville to advance to the CWS finals falling in two games to the national champion LSU Tigers. Chanticleer alum, head coach Kevin Schnall guided CCU to the most wins in school history with 56 in 2025.

Top story #5 ‚Äì After coming oh so close to winning his first title on the PGA Tour, Academic Magnet alum Andrew Novak would fall in a playoff at the Heritage to Justin Thomas. Andrew would rebound the following week winning the Zurich Classic with playing partner Ben Griffin for his first title on tour. Novak capped off 2025 by winning another team event, the Grant Thornton Invitational with l-p-g-a‚Äôs Lauren Coughlin.

Top story #4 ‚Äì Dr. Quinn gave Nicols college the medicine in October as Stratford alum Montie Quinn set a new NCAA single game rushing record across all divisions as he ran for an absurd 522 yards on just 20 carries in Currie College‚Äôs 71 ‚Äì 27 victory. Montie added seven touchdowns, his longest coming from 85 yards and finished the season with 2446 rushing yards. Once again leading the NCAA across all divisions.

Top story #3 ‚Äì SC State won the MEAC title for a second year in a row under Chennis Berry. The Bulldogs would play in the Celebration Bowl for a second year in a row as well. After falling by 21 in 2024, they trailed by 21 at the half against Prairie View A&M. SCSU responded in the third quarter tying things at 21 and would go on to force overtime. In the fourth OT, SC State scored the first two point try then stopped the Panthers attempt as pandemonium reigned and confetti fell as the Bulldogs claimed the HBCU national title for the first time since 2021.

Top story #2 ‚Äì While the Bulldogs won a title in the ATL, OCA won a third straight title in Orangeburg on State‚Äôs home turf. Oceanside punished BHP for a second year in a row winning back to back 3A state titles, the third overall title in a row as Brent LaPrad became the third different head coach to win a championship with the Landsharks. OCA became the first Lowcountry program to three-peat since Summerville from 1982-1984.

Top story #1 ‚Äì After winning gold in the 4√ó100 relay at the Paris Olympics in 2024, Georgetown‚Äôs Melissa Jefferson-Wooden became the fastest woman in the world as she set a new world record in the 100 meters at the World Athletics Championship in Tokyo with a blazing time of 10.61 seconds. Jefferson-Wooden would go on to win the 200 meters at the championship as well.

title: Broncos Survive Again, Outlast Chiefs, 20-13, To Remain Top Seed In AFC
description: The Denver Broncos once again played down to their competition against a Kansas City Chiefs team forced to play its third-string quarterback, but the Broncos somehow managed to overcome their struggles to win, 20-13 in a problematic game that once agains exposed their limitations.
fullText:
The Denver Broncos once again played down to their competition against a Kansas City Chiefs team forced to play its third-string quarterback, but the Broncos somehow managed to overcome their struggles to win, 20-13 in a problematic game that once agains exposed their limitations.

This game was defined by four long Denver drives, one in each quarter. The first two came up short to produce a pair of Wil Lutz field goals, with gave the Chiefs a chance to hang around and counter with a touchdown on a short drive after a Bo Nix interception to make the score 7-6 at halftime.

The Chiefs actually scored first in the third quarter after a pass interference penalty on Broncos cornerback Pat Surtain II gave KC the ball in Denver territory, which led to a 53-yard field goal by Chiefs kicker Harrison Butker that made it 10-6.

The Broncos proceeded to drive the field again, and this time Nix was able to finish by running the ball in from nine yards out for Denver‚Äôs first touchdown of the night. That gave the Broncos the lead, 13-10, but the Chiefs were able to counter with yet another Butker field goal from 47 yards after a 44-yard punt return by running back Brashard Smith.

Denver‚Äôs final drive of the game was the fourth one to last for at least 14 plays, and Nix finished the 65-yard effort with a one-yard touchdown pass to running back RJ Harvey. The key play in the drive was a defensive offside penalty by Chiefs tackle Chris Jones that gave Denver a critical red-zone first down that led to the score.,

The Broncos were lucky to win this one, and Kansas City‚Äôs last-ditch scoring attempt featured some receiving heroics from Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce. But a final pass to receiver Hollywood Brown in the end zone in the final seconds ended up bing an overthrow that allowed Denver to survive.

Nix was decidedly mediocre, producing just 182 yards passing as he went 26-for-38, and his longest throw of the night went for just 10 yards. The Broncos also struggled to run the ball effectively for most of the night, and it was this combination that allowed the Chiefs to stay within striking distance.

The Denver defense did what it had to do against third-string Chiefs quarterback Chris Oladokun, but there were some scary moments when bad tackling in the secondary once again nearly cost them. Oladokun passed for just 66 yards on the night as he went 13-for-22, but the fact that the Chiefs were in this one at all was mostly a testimony to the Broncos‚Äô ongoing struggles.

The win gave Denver the pole position in the race for the top seed in the AFC, but it‚Äôs hard to imagine the Broncos making a deep playoff run given their lack of a running game and Nix‚Äôs ongoing issues with inconsistency. There‚Äôs a lot to fix before their final game against the Los Angeles Chargers, and that game will be for the AFC West title if the Chargers can defeat the Houston Texans on Saturday.

The Chiefs played valiantly given their offensive limitations and the fact that this game was meaningless for them, and they‚Äôll wrap up their broken season with a road game against the Las Vegas Raiders that promises to feature some ugly football given where both teams are right now.

title: Before the Year Turns and the Miles Begin, Cowboys are Home For Christmas Again
description: Merry Christmas from all of us at Rodeo Roundtable!
fullText:
The chutes are quiet, and the lights are low
another season comes and go.

Boots by the door, hats on the wall
No entry fees due, no late, night call.¬†
For a moment, the miles don‚Äôt matter at all
Because family is where it starts, and where they fall.

Rocker Steiner chased a lifelong dream,
and through setbacks, doubt, and in-between
his first gold buckle, hard-earned pride
mow shared with those who stood beside.

Tucker Allen holds his buckle tight, 
grateful for the hands that made it right
Banker, hazers, the team it took,
his first world title written in the book.

Taylor Munsell made history, rope in her hand
a first gold buckle earned, it was the plan.
Cole Patterson adds another to the case,
as years of hard work are reflected in champion‚Äôs pace.

Andrew Ward and Jake Long stayed patient and true,
they let one last steer tell the story through,
just did their part
They claimed a title with veteran heart.

In the saddle bronc, the story stayed
three Wrights on top, history made.
The youngest brother, still the same. 
Family legacy, but making his own name.

Riley Webb kept quiet, did the work, stayed true,
he Let God handle the noise and records came through.
looking up before looking ahead
and thankful for the path his faith had led.

Kassie Mowry trusted feel more than fame, 
different horses, same belief, same game.
she stands now with gold buckle two,
and is the greatest to ever do what she do.

Stetson Wright kept climbing still
a comeback built on grit and will. 
Ten gold buckles, the job‚Äôs not through
Superman proves what he can do.

Now a new year and the planning starts
new goals are forming in steady hearts. 
The next season waits beyond the gate,
¬†but family still sets the starting place.

Stockings hang where buckles too now lay
¬†it is a reminder that work can always wait a day.

They‚Äôll head back out now as the calendar turns
with fresh resolve and lessons learned.

The work never ends for the cowboy way,
and there‚Äôs always another road, another day. 
But Christmas slows the pace for a time,
it is a breath before the next uphill climb.

Before the year turns and the miles begin,
the cowboys come back home, and it all starts again.

title: United by birth, bound by football: Two brothers‚Äô journey to the NFL
description: For two identical twin brothers, a bond could be centered around anything, but for the Bell boys it was always football.
fullText:
WICHITA, Kan. (KSNW) ‚Äî From the moment they hit the gridiron, Mike and Blake Bell were inseparable.

For two identical twin brothers, a bond could be centered around anything, but for the Bell boys it was always football.

For nearly their entire lives, they were on the same team. In high school both attended Bishop Carroll, in college they both played for Colorado State, but on draft day things took a turn. Taken second overall by the Chiefs, Mike made Mark a promise.

‚ÄúThe sports information guy said I needed to get over to Kansas City, and I told them, I wasn‚Äôt leaving until Mark got drafted,‚Äù said Mike Bell.

After three rounds, Mark eventually got drafted in the fourth. In a time crunch, Mike would have to leave for Kansas City, but on the way there, he quickly learned that Mark was taken by an AFC West rival.

Maize senior shooting guard leads by example on and off the field

‚ÄúI‚Äôm flying to Kansas City, and as I‚Äôm getting off the plane, the pilot comes out and says, I just wanna let you know they radioed up and your brother got drafted to the Seahawks,‚Äù said Mike Bell.

The two faced off twice a year on the opposite side of the ball, with Mike eventually getting the best of Mark in their NFL debut.

‚ÄúThe first play wasn‚Äôt that good for me,‚Äù Mark said laughingly. ‚ÄúWe had some really great memories, though. My mom and dad and the whole family would bring a bus down to Arrowhead to come watch us play, it was really special.‚Äù

And with all of those great memories, come a legacy that the two brothers will share forever.

‚ÄúThey remember us as the football guys, even though we‚Äôve done different things since then, it‚Äôs amazing how that kind of follows you and it just goes with you for your whole life,‚Äù said Mike Bell.

For more Kansas news,¬†click here. Keep up with the latest breaking news by downloading our¬†mobile app¬†and signing up for our¬†news email alerts. To watch our shows live on our website, click here.

title: Q&A: ‚ÄòHeated Rivalry‚Äô director hopes NHL welcomes new eyes
description: ‚ÄòHeated Rivalry‚Äô director Jacob Tierney talks hockey culture, the NHL‚Äôs response, and why Ilya and Shane have drawn new eyes to the sport.
fullText:
Heated Rivalry has inspired watch parties, fan edits, and a level of obsession usually reserved for playoff runs. It has also found its way into NHL buildings.

For director Jacob Tierney, that response raises a bigger question: Can a TV show from Canada ‚Äî adapted from Rachel Reid‚Äôs Game Changer book series with the help of HBO ‚Äî help hockey reach beyond its usual audience? Now that the finale at the cottage has aired, it seems clear the answer is yes.

Tierney suspected he had bronchitis when he spoke to USA TODAY‚Äôs For The Win and was on antibiotics, the result of a nonstop press tour promoting the show‚Äôs occasionally spicy queer hockey romance centered on the magnetic Shane Hollander and Ilya Rozanov, played by Hudson Williams and Connor Storrie.

More: 'Heated Rivalry' stars, sexuality rumors and what we can learn

The show has grown so big that the NHL released a statement addressing its impact and influence (via The Hollywood Reporter):

‚ÄúThere are so many ways to get hooked on hockey and, in the NHL‚Äôs 108-year history, this might be the most unique driver for creating new fans. See you all at the rink.‚Äù

That surge in popularity has also meant that Williams and Storrie have gone from virtually unknown to overnight stars.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just happy it‚Äôs working. I‚Äôm delighted,‚Äù Tierney told For The Win. ‚ÄúPeople seem to like it, and that‚Äôs what matters.‚Äù

Fans have gathered in sports bars to watch the show‚Äôs biggest moments as if they were Stanley Cup games ‚Äî and they‚Äôve noticed everything. That includes Easter eggs ranging from Hollander‚Äôs heartbeat matching Rozanov‚Äôs jersey number to needle drops timed perfectly to pivotal plot points.

‚ÄúHonestly, people have noticed everything ‚Äî things I didn‚Äôt even consciously put in,‚Äù Tierney said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never felt so observed in my life.‚Äù

Some of those songs from the soundtrack, like "I'll Believe in Anything" and "All the Things She Said" have massively spiked with listeners.

For The Win caught up with Tierney to discuss the viral series, its breakout stars Williams and Storrie, co-star Fran√ßois Arnaud, the soundtrack fueling the show‚Äôs momentum, and the NHL and Montreal Canadiens ‚Äî also known as the Habs.

Fans can watch the first season of Heated Rivalry, which was recently renewed for a second season, on HBO Max.

This interview has been condensed and edited for clarity.

More: Andrew Scott surprises 'Heated Rivalry' star in sweet podcast moment

Tierney: I‚Äôve been doing this a long time. I knew we had something really good, but that doesn‚Äôt always matter. There‚Äôs so much noise now ‚Äî so much TV, so much content. I knew we had a good show, and once HBO picked it up, I knew we had a fighting chance to get noticed. But everything that‚Äôs happened since has been completely insane. I never could have predicted any of this.

We were never going to cast stars in these roles. That was always the idea. I think romance as a genre is often better served by lesser-known actors, because the audience can really project onto the characters rather than a pre-existing persona. With something like this, it was important that they could just be Ilya and Shane ‚Äî not bring other baggage into it. The level of alchemy has been wild. We definitely didn‚Äôt anticipate anything like this.

Tierney: It‚Äôs a great question. I think you have to wait and see what these things actually do. But it‚Äôs incredibly cool that someone in the Bruins organization and someone with the Habs are clearly really into it and keep playing our songs. That‚Äôs [expletive] amazing.

I‚Äôm born and raised in Montreal ‚Äî the Habs are a religion where I‚Äôm from ‚Äî so every time they show our trailer playing on the Jumbotron, it‚Äôs so [expletive] cool.

I hope what the NHL said yesterday is sincere, that they really are valuing new eyes and the new air that comes with that. Hockey is a sport I love deeply, but it doesn‚Äôt always reach beyond its core fan base. I think it could use a little crack, a little oxygen getting in there.

The NHL seems to function like the Catholic Church in terms of its insularity. People say that with Habs all the time: Only the Habs do pageantry better than the Catholic Church.

There‚Äôs a stoicism to hockey, a desire for this monolithic image, and I think the sport can survive a lot more than that. I don‚Äôt imagine a culture shift but even if it‚Äôs just moving an inch to the left, I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs a bad thing. Ultimately, the bigger the audience, the better for the sport.

Rachel Reid and I are huge hockey fans. This show is a love letter to hockey in its own way. It was never made to slight the sport ‚Äî that‚Äôs just not true.

Tierney: I have a friend who said to me recently: ‚ÄúDo people know that the soundtrack is just a playlist you made in 2008?‚Äù Fair enough. These are just songs that I love that speak to me.

I‚Äôve been a Wolf Parade fan since their first EP. With Feist, I grew up with Broken Social Scene and that whole explosion of Canadian music, which was incredibly meaningful to me. I love music, and I‚Äôm always looking for new stuff too ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs Wet Leg or whatever connects with me now.

If a song moves me, and it works with the images, hopefully it moves other people too. The reaction to the music has been really rewarding. Wolf Parade actually sent me a lovely note yesterday ‚Äî they were really happy. And ‚ÄúI‚Äôll Believe in Anything‚Äù is an anthem and it deserves all the attention it‚Äôs getting. It‚Äôs an amazing song.

Tierney: You‚Äôre already seeing shifts with younger players being aware of their own mental health and trying to take care of yourself. The NHL has made some good efforts, like the Player Assistance Program. There is a desire there.

A lot of traditionally masculine cultures struggle with allowing people to say things out loud. Not every bit of vulnerability has to be presented behind closed doors. You can be vulnerable and still have the mental and physical toughness required to be a professional athlete.

If anything, vulnerability is attractive. It‚Äôs not harmful, and it‚Äôs good for your mental health.

Tierney: I don‚Äôt think it changes that much. I‚Äôve always described this as a workplace romance ‚Äî hockey is their workplace. I love hockey, but I wanted to make a show where you don‚Äôt need to understand icing to follow the story. It‚Äôs about rivalry and competition, about winning and losing.

Someone tweeted that they were glad the hockey ‚Äúfades to black‚Äù on Heated Rivalry, which made me laugh because that‚Äôs usually how sex is treated.

There actually is a fair amount of hockey in the show, and our hockey coordinator did a [expletive] great job. It looks good.

But this was never going to be a show where you get an episode that‚Äôs just a full game. That‚Äôs not happening. Hockey is still the beating heart of the show, though ‚Äî and you‚Äôll definitely get more of it in the second season.

This article originally appeared on For The Win: Heated Rivalry director Jacob Tierney on Ilya and Shane, hockey fans

title: Travis Kelce leaves field with a smile in potential final game at Arrowhead Stadium amid retirement speculation
description: Donna Kelce and Taylor Swift were on hand Thursday night to watch Travis Kelce and the Chiefs.
fullText:
Travis Kelce walked off the field at Arrowhead Stadium with a smile Thursday night, seemingly in good spirits. While we still don‚Äôt know if that was it for him at the stadium in Kansas City, and the 20-13 loss to the Denver Broncos wasn‚Äôt the best way to go out, Kelce still got plenty of love from Chiefs fans on his way out the door.

Kelce‚Äôs mom, Donna, and his fianc√©e, Taylor Swift, were in attendance, too. The walk back to the locker room this time felt different.

Travis Kelce walks off the field after his last home game of the season ü´∂ @tkelce | @chiefs pic.twitter.com/5keiEj8Hvu

‚ÄúYou only get a few of those where you just get to stand there and appreciate 60-70,000 Chiefs fans screaming for you,‚Äù Kelce said in his postgame news conference. ‚ÄúI always embrace that moment, man. It‚Äôs fun. Hopefully I got everybody fired up for it.‚Äù

Kelce has spent his entire career with the Chiefs, who selected him in the third round of the 2013 NFL Draft out of Cincinnati. He quickly became a fan favorite and played an integral part of the Chiefs‚Äô dynastic run and their three Super Bowl wins. His public relationship with Swift has only skyrocketed his fame over the past several years.

The 11-time Pro Bowler is closing in on 13,000 career receiving yards and has 82 touchdowns on 1,077 catches over his 13 seasons in the league. All three of those figures are the most in franchise history. He had five catches for 36 yards Thursday night.

But at 36, Kelce is undoubtedly nearing the end of his career. There has been plenty of speculation that he may retire at the end of the season, especially considering the Chiefs are going to miss the playoffs for the first time since Kelce‚Äôs second season in the league. Quarterback Patrick Mahomes is recovering from an ACL and LCL injury he suffered earlier this month, making the start of next season unclear.

If Kelce were to retire after this season, which would mark the end of an era for the franchise that has dominated the league in recent years, Thursday‚Äôs game would be his final one at home. He's at the end of a two-year, $34.25 million deal with the team and would become a free agent in the coming months.

Kelce declined to give much clarity on the speculation postgame.

‚ÄúHonestly, I‚Äôve been just focused on trying to win football games, man,‚Äù Kelce said about retirement. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll let that be a decision that I make with my family, friends, the Chiefs organization when the time comes.‚Äù

The Chiefs will take on the Las Vegas Raiders next weekend to wrap up their season. Based on Kelce‚Äôs comments Thursday night, we won‚Äôt have an answer on his future until after that.

But if this was the end, considering the circumstances, Kelce sure took advantage of his final moments at Arrowhead.

title: JJ Redick rips Lakers with 4-word message after brutal Rockets loss
description: Lakers head coach JJ Redick ripped into the team following a poor Christmas Day performance against the Rockets.
fullText:
JJ Redick rips Lakers with 4-word message after brutal Rockets loss appeared first on ClutchPoints. 

LOS ANGELES ‚Äì The Los Angeles Lakers‚Äô current losing streak hit three games following their 119-96 loss to the Houston Rockets on Christmas Day. For the Lakers, there are plenty of issues to discuss in regards to their poor play as of late. But for head coach JJ Redick, the ultimate reason for the team‚Äôs recent stretch can be summed up in four simple words.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt care enough,‚Äù Redick said following the Lakers‚Äô Christmas Day loss to the Rockets. ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs the part that bothers me a lot. We don‚Äôt care enough to do the things that are necessary, and we don‚Äôt care enough to be a professional. We had it, we had it. I always say this about culture, I always say this about a good team being a functioning organism, it can change like that. We don‚Äôt have it right now.‚Äù

From the opening tip, the Lakers were a step slower than the Rockets on both ends of the court. They found themselves trailing by double digits early in the first quarter, 18-8, and by the end of the period they were down 37-25.

It was still a double digit deficit at halftime, and the second half didn‚Äôt get any better with the Rockets‚Äô lead ballooning to 20 points almost midway through the third quarter. The Lakers couldn‚Äôt rebound, they couldn‚Äôt get stops and they couldn‚Äôt string together enough consistency offensively. To make matters worse, Austin Reaves was ruled out for the second half due to his ongoing calf injury. In the first half, Reaves had been the only consistent offensive threat for the team.

JJ Redick didn‚Äôt hold back words when summing up what kind of team the Lakers are right now, while acknowledging that he told the team postgame to expect an uncomfortable practice this weekend.

‚ÄúThe two words of the day were effort and execution. I feel like when we‚Äôve done both those things at a high level, we‚Äôve been a good basketball team,‚Äù Redick said. ‚ÄúWhen we haven‚Äôt, we‚Äôre a terrible basketball team, and tonight we were a terrible basketball team. That started legitimately right away.‚Äù

The Lakers were outrebounded by the Rockets, 48-25. They allowed 24 second chance points compared to their 10, and 16 fastbreak points compared to their 11.

Tuesday‚Äôs loss against the Phoenix Suns was the first time this season that the Lakers had lost consecutive games. Redick had vowed that the Lakers would have the right mentality on Christmas, but that was not the case. The Lakers‚Äô next opportunity to get back in the win column is Sunday, Dec. 28 as the Sacramento Kings come to town.

title: Lakers coach JJ Redick promises 'uncomfortable' practice after third straight loss: 'Tonight, we were a terrible basketball team'
description: The Lakers' head coach is one of their loudest critics right now.
fullText:
Los Angeles Lakers head coach JJ Redick was not in a charitable mood after the team‚Äôs 119-96 loss to the Houston Rockets on Christmas Day.

The team took its third straight loss Thursday in a one-sided affair, an outcome made worse by rising star Austin Reaves exiting the game with another calf injury. The Rockets led by double-digits for the entire second half and outrebounded the Lakers 48-25.

After the game, Redick railed against his team‚Äôs effort level and bluntly assessed how it performed:

‚ÄúThe two words of the day were ‚Äòeffort‚Äô and ‚Äòexecution.‚Äô I feel like when we‚Äôve done both of those things at a high level, we‚Äôve been a good basketball team. When we haven‚Äôt, we‚Äôre a terrible basketball team. And tonight, we were a terrible basketball team.‚Äù

He went on to note the team‚Äôs next practice Saturday will not be a fun one for certain players, whose consistency he is directly questioning:

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt care enough right now. That‚Äôs the part that bothers me a lot. We don‚Äôt care enough to do the things that are necessary. We don‚Äôt care enough to be professional.

It‚Äôs a matter of making the choice, and too often we have guys that don‚Äôt want to make that choice. It‚Äôs pretty consistent who those guys are. Saturday‚Äôs practice, I told the guys, it‚Äôs going to be uncomfortable. Meeting is going to be uncomfortable. I‚Äôm not doing another 53 games like this.‚Äù

That choice calls back to what Redick said after the Lakers‚Äô previous loss to the Phoenix Suns, in which he painted the team‚Äôs defensive effort as a series of choices it wasn‚Äôt making correctly.

His full postgame conference Thursday:

JJ Redick went scorched earth on the Lakers postgame. pic.twitter.com/ZLuOKyqMBQ

‚Äî Arash Markazi (@ArashMarkazi) December 26, 2025

The Lakers have spent nearly the entire season on solid footing despite LeBron James‚Äô early season absence, but now sit at 19-10, good for only fifth place in the Western Conference. The team can only hope Reaves isn‚Äôt further injured after missing three games last week with a calf strain, but it has other problems to figure out now.

The Lakers‚Äô next chance to get back on track will be a Sunday home game against the Sacramento Kings, who currently hold the worst record in the West at 7-23.

title: Lakers don‚Äôt care enough and that has to change now
description: Something has to change with the Lakers. That much was clear to Lakers coach JJ Redick and anyone else who saw the Lakers get blown out for a third straight game.
fullText:
LOS ANGELES ‚Äî Something has to change with the Lakers.

That was the feeling most Lakers fans had as they exited Crypto.com Arena early on Christmas, hoping to beat traffic after a third straight blowout loss. It was a sentiment echoed loudly by Lakers coach JJ Redick after the final buzzer and one likely to be shared by general manager Rob Pelinka soon enough.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt care enough right now,‚Äù Redick said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the part that bothers you a lot. We don‚Äôt care enough to do the things that are necessary. We don‚Äôt care enough to be professional. We don‚Äôt care enough to be professional.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a matter of making the choice, and far too often we don‚Äôt have guys who want to make that choice,‚Äù Redick added while previewing the team‚Äôs next practice. ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs pretty consistent who those guys are. Saturday‚Äôs practice, I told the guys, is going to be uncomfortable. The meeting is going to be uncomfortable. I‚Äôm not doing another 53 games like this.‚Äù

JJ Redick went scorched earth on the Lakers postgame. pic.twitter.com/ZLuOKyqMBQ

‚Äî Arash Markazi (@ArashMarkazi) December 26, 2025

For a franchise that entered the season believing it had solved its championship formula, Christmas offered a brutal reality check.

The NBA trade deadline is February 5, 2026 ‚Äî 41 days from the moment the Lakers exited the court Thursday following a 119‚Äì96 loss to the Houston Rockets. It marked their longest losing streak of the season, a stunning reversal for a team that hadn‚Äôt even lost consecutive games before last Saturday.

That night, the Clippers handed them a 103‚Äì88 loss. On Tuesday, the Phoenix Suns obliterated them 132‚Äì88. On Thursday, the Rockets delivered the third punch of a six-day stretch that has reframed the Lakers‚Äô season and exposed their ceiling.

This is not a championship team as currently constructed.

Yes, they started 15‚Äì4 and looked like a contender through 19 games. But as Stan Van Gundy told me at the NBA Cup, numbers eventually win every argument.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think they‚Äôre a true contender, in my opinion,‚Äù Van Gundy said ¬†‚ÄúTheir numbers said they were mediocre. Their record said they were really good. I just don‚Äôt think in today‚Äôs game they have enough.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt have the depth, they don‚Äôt have the speed and quickness to keep up right now,‚Äù Van Gundy continued. ‚ÄúDefensively, they even get weaker when their three best players play together.‚Äù

He was referring to the Lakers‚Äô high-usage trio ‚Äî Luka Donƒçiƒá, LeBron James, and Austin Reaves ‚Äî a combination that has repeatedly failed to defend young, fast, perimeter-driven teams. Against Houston, those stars once again shared the floor alongside starters Deandre Ayton and Rui Hachimura. The result was predictable.

The Lakers‚Äô starting lineup was a -14 in just over eight minutes in the first half with a defensive rating of 144.4. Entering the game, that unit posted a 113 offensive rating, 122 defensive rating, and a -9 net rating this season.

‚ÄúWhen they had the mix of two of those guys (they were better).‚Äù Van Gundy said of the Lakers when they played without one of their stars. ‚ÄúNow JJ will obviously rotate those guys, but they‚Äôre going to come down the stretch in games, and those three guys are all going to be out there and Ayton will be out there and now you can‚Äôt get perimeter defenders out there with them. I think it‚Äôs a struggle and JJ and his staff have a huge challenge in front of them.‚Äù

James' Rich Paul said it first when he claimed the Lakers weren't a contender on his podcast two weeks ago. Van Gundy validated it. And the last 72 hours have cemented it.

The Lakers are 19‚Äì10 ‚Äî fifth in the West, just ahead of the Rockets and the Suns, two teams that dismantled them. National hype can cloak flaws for only so long. The Lakers‚Äô fatal flaw is now their defining one:

They cannot defend young, fast teams, and no team wins in the postseason giving up 120 points a night.

The Lakers don‚Äôt need another superstar. They have that box checked with Donƒçiƒá. They still get All-NBA moments from LeBron. They‚Äôll likely send Reaves to his first All-Star Game. But stars without an identity ‚Äî without depth, speed, or defensive toughness ‚Äî are just names on a marquee, not threats in a playoff series.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt picture them on OKC‚Äôs level,‚Äù Van Gundy said. ‚ÄúDenver, San Antonio, Houston are probably the next three teams, and I don‚Äôt see the Lakers at that level.‚Äù

The good news? There‚Äôs still time for Pelinka to fix what ails them. The bad news? Time is the only thing they have. And if urgency, pride, and professionalism don‚Äôt arrive soon, it won‚Äôt matter who sits in uncomfortable practices or who speaks into a microphone next.

The Lakers‚Äô biggest issue isn‚Äôt schematic, roster-based, or philosophical.

It‚Äôs effort. It‚Äôs identity. It‚Äôs caring enough.

And right now, they simply don‚Äôt.

title: Rockets-Lakers takeaways: L.A. certainly doesn't have the look of a title threat
description: Here are three reasons why the Lakers were thrashed on Christmas Day.
fullText:
The Houston Rockets celebrated Christmas in style, delivering an overwhelming and dominant outing in a 119-96 thrashing of the Los Angeles Lakers on Thursday.

Amen Thompson led six Rockets in double figures with 26 points in the win, which ended a brutal six-game road trip ‚Äî three overtime losses plus a 20-point blowout at the hands of the woeful Clippers¬†‚Äî on a strong note to improve to 18-10 on the season. Luka Donƒçiƒá scored a team-high 25 points for the Lakers, but also committed six of their 16 turnovers in a game L.A. never led, and in which Donƒçiƒá, LeBron James and Co. only briefly even appeared competitive.

Here are three takeaways from the Rockets‚Äô commanding performance at Crypto.com Arena:

After consecutive blowout losses to the Clippers and Suns, L.A. head coach JJ Redick offered a curt reply to an inquiry as to whether his Lakers ‚Äî who entered Christmas ranked 25th in defensive efficiency ‚Äî had shown enough of a willingness to dig in and grind it out on the less glamorous end of the floor:

Reporter: "Does this group have enough guys who make the choice to play hard (like many guys on Phoenix eg. Goodwin)?"

JJ Redick: "No."

‚Äî Lakers Daily (@LakersDailyCom) December 24, 2025

L.A. brought a similar flavor of indifference for much of its Christmas Day matchup with Houston. The Lakers repeatedly allowed Rockets ball-handlers to beat them at the point of attack, get into the paint and generate good look after good look, seemingly whenever and wherever they wanted:

Amen Thompson with the speedy layup and then the Alley-oop dunk off a lob by Alperen Sengun (with a replay) pic.twitter.com/bVKRE8aCr0

‚Äî MrBuckBuck (@MrBuckBuckNBA) December 26, 2025

Houston barely needed five minutes of game time to build a double-figure lead that it would never relinquish, ending the opening frame with 37 points on 24 possessions ‚Äî a torrid 154.2 offensive rating. For reference, the best offense in the NBA, the Denver Nuggets, scores 125.6 points-per-100.

‚ÄúThe two words of the day were ‚Äòeffort‚Äô and ‚Äòexecution,‚Äô‚Äù Redick said after the game. ‚ÄúI feel like when we‚Äôve done both of those things at a high level, we‚Äôve been a good basketball team, and when we haven‚Äôt, we‚Äôre a terrible basketball team. And tonight, we were a terrible basketball team. And that started, legitimately, right away.‚Äù

When the Lakers briefly made a push midway through the second quarter, cutting the deficit to four at 48-44 following 3-pointers by Donƒçiƒá and Jarred Vanderbilt, the Rockets calmly stuck to their guns, scored 15 points in the next three minutes and pushed the lead back to 10 at halftime. After the Rockets opened the third quarter with buckets on four straight possessions, Redick shifted tactics and dialed up a zone, which resulted in a pair of stops ‚Ä¶ which Houston promptly rendered irrelevant by grabbing offensive rebounds, scoring second-chance points and extending its lead even further.

Redick rifled through his Rolodex in search of different combinations that might offer a level of physicality and defensive activity that could short-circuit Houston‚Äôs smoothly operating machine. The combo of Vanderbilt and Marcus Smart helped key an 11-4 second-quarter run that constituted L.A.‚Äôs best basketball of the night; a unit flanking Donƒçiƒá and whisper-quiet center Deandre Ayton with Vanderbilt, Smart, gap-plugging connector Jake LaRavia (one that had played just 10 possessions together all season prior to Thursday) showed intermittent sparks.

For the most part, though, the Lakers‚Äô Christmas fizzle looked remarkably similar to their Emirates NBA Cup quarterfinals loss to the San Antonio Spurs: a team top-heavy with scoring skill but light on size, athleticism and defensive steel proving unable ‚Äî or unwilling ‚Äî to hang with a younger, stronger, more physical and more relentless opponent.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt care enough right now,‚Äù Redick said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the part that bothers you a lot. We don‚Äôt care enough to, like, do the things that are necessary. We don‚Äôt care enough to be a professional. We had it. We had it. I always say this about culture, I always say this about a team being a functioning organism: It can change like that. We don‚Äôt have it right now.‚Äù

What the Lakers do have, in Donƒçiƒá, James and Austin Reaves (who sat out the second half with what the Lakers called left calf soreness, a worrying note considering he just missed three games with a calf strain) is enough high-end scoring and playmaking to produce a top-flight offense. If they can‚Äôt provide a higher class of resistance against similarly skilled opponents, though, that won‚Äôt be enough ‚Äî especially not if the goal is to make a deep postseason run in this Western Conference.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a matter of making the choice, and too often, we have guys who don‚Äôt want to make that choice,‚Äù Redick said. ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs pretty consistent who those guys are. I told the guys: Saturday‚Äôs practice is going to be uncomfortable. The meeting is going to be uncomfortable. I‚Äôm not doing another 53 games like this.‚Äù

Coming into Christmas Day, the Rockets were the NBA‚Äôs sixth-best team at winning the possession battle on a night-to-night basis, according to analysis by Jared Dubin at Last Night in Basketball, averaging three more offensive trips per game than their opponents. They pressed that advantage early and often Thursday, pulling down four offensive rebounds against some lackadaisical Lakers boxouts and forcing six turnovers in the first quarter alone.

That allowed them to take five more shots than L.A. in the opening stanza ‚Äî a key factor in the Rockets opening that early double-digit lead and keeping the Lakers at arm‚Äôs length.

17 offensive rebounds for Houston ‚Äî an obscene 55.6% offensive rebounding rate, per @cleantheglass ‚Äî and 24 second-chance points. The Rockets do this to everybody, but the defensive rebounding just wasn't even close to good enough for the Lakers. pic.twitter.com/kGMysOf9Nr

‚Äî Dan Devine (@YourManDevine) December 26, 2025

The Rockets finished with nearly as many offensive rebounds (17) as the Lakers had defensive rebounds (18) and monster edges in second-chance points (24-10), points off turnovers (23-11), points scored per possession in transition (1.33 to 1.13) and total field-goal attempts (90-77). Getting that many more bites at the apple, and capitalizing on them so effectively, is how the Rockets can shrug off 25 from Luka and the Lakers shooting 50.6% as a team overall ‚Äî and how a Houston team that takes fewer 3-pointers per game than any other squad in the NBA can still boast one of the league‚Äôs most potent and efficient attacks.

When they‚Äôre at their best, the Rockets come at you in waves on the offensive end. It‚Äôs Thompson (26 points on 12-for-19 shooting with five assists) repeatedly getting downhill into the paint, and Alperen ≈ûeng√ºn (14 points, 12 rebounds, four assists) meanspiritedly pirouetting his way into all manner of infuriating flip shots and needle-threading drop-offs, and Kevin Durant (25 points on 8-for-14 shooting, eight assists) barely seeming to break a sweat as he gets to his preferred spots in the midrange or pops a trail 3 in an unsuspecting defender‚Äôs eye.

When they‚Äôre really scary, it‚Äôs because those headliners have help: Jabari Smith Jr. (16 points on nine shots) drilling jumpers spotting up and running off pindowns, Reed Sheppard (13 points, 5-for-10 from the floor) snaking the pick-and-roll to get to CP3-style elbow pull-ups in rhythm, and Tari Eason ‚Äî an absolute menace on both ends of the court, just fully Grinching it up ‚Äî ripping and running and terrorizing.

7 quick points for Tari Eason pic.twitter.com/rsnFfX1BBL

‚Äî MrBuckBuck (@MrBuckBuckNBA) December 26, 2025

Amen Thompson with the alley-oop dunk off a lob by Kevin Durant to put the Rockets up 22 (with replays) pic.twitter.com/25gOMqUmrY

‚Äî MrBuckBuck (@MrBuckBuckNBA) December 26, 2025

On some nights, the lack of a proper half-court organizer of a point guard will rear its ugly head; on others, though, the sheer tonnage of Houston‚Äôs athleticism, ferocity and talent will dispense with any such concerns. On those nights, these Rockets can straight up run you out of your gym. Ask the Lakers. They can tell you all about it.

title: Warriors GM Mike Dunleavy Jr. downplays trade talk
description: Dunleavy remains confident in the Warriors despite their uneven start.
fullText:
Warriors GM Mike Dunleavy Jr. downplays trade talk originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Golden State Warriors have had an up-and-down start to the season, sitting at 16-15.

Talks about the Warriors making a blockbuster trade to shake up the team's roster. But General Manager Mike Dunleavy Jr. doesn't anticipate a deal like that happening anytime soon.

"We'll look to do stuff that makes our team better, but I wouldn't bank on that type of move," Dunleavy said on "Warriors Pregame Live".

Dunleavy is still bullish on this Warriors team despite their uneven start.

"The key with this team, frankly, right now and moving forward is improving from within," Dunleavy said. "The biggest area we know is turnovers. We've got to start taking care of the ball. We're doing some really good stuff."

One issue for the Warriors this season has been turnovers. Golden State commits 15.6 turnovers per game, which ranks 29th in the NBA. Dunleavy said the Warriors will be fine if they can protect the basketball.

"Right now there's a little too much talk about fixing the roster and some of these other things going on. It's all right in front of us. We've got to take care of the ball, and we'll be good."

MORE:¬†Ben Simmons is going pro in a sport you'd never expect

Golden State has had several role players emerge this season. Rookie Will Richard has been the biggest surprise, as he's averaging 8.1 points and shooting 41.8% from deep. Dunleavy thinks the Warriors have plenty of depth.

"These guys can come in when they need to and play five, six minutes, and be really productive for us," Dunleavy said. "I think you've got to build a team this day and age that has depth."

Dunleavy is confident the Warriors will make their playoff push when head coach Steve Kerr finds a consistent rotation of players.

"We've got a good, deep roster," Dunleavy said. "We'd like to find some consistency here. And I think with consistency in lineups, that will probably lead to consistency in winning."

title: Chiefs Fall Short Against Broncos, 20-13, Due To Offensive Limitations
description: Give credit to the Kansas City Chiefs defense, and to tight end Travis Kelce‚Äîthey both came to play, and as a result the Chiefs were nearly able to pull off an improbable upset against the Denver Broncos, but the Chiefs‚Äô offensive limitations ultimately resulted in a 20-13 loss.
fullText:
Give credit to the Kansas City Chiefs defense, and to tight end Travis Kelce‚Äîthey both came to play, and as a result the Chiefs were nearly able to pull off an improbable upset against the Denver Broncos, but the Chiefs‚Äô offensive limitations ultimately resulted in a 20-13 loss.

This game was defined by four long Denver drives, one in each quarter. The first two came up short to produce a pair of Wil Lutz field goals, with gave the Chiefs a chance to hang around and counter with a touchdown on a short drive after a Bo Nix interception to make the score 7-6 at halftime.

The TD came on a 4-yard pass to running back Brashard Smith, and it was the first career touchdown bass for the Chiefs third-string quarterback, Chris Oladokun.

The Chiefs actually scored first in the third quarter after a pass interference penalty on Broncos cornerback Pat Surtain II in Denver territory led to a 53-yard field goal by Chiefs kicker Harrison Butker that made it 10-6.

The Broncos proceeded to drive the field again, and this time Nix was able to finish by running the ball in from nine yards out for Denver‚Äôs first touchdown of the night. That gave the Broncos the lead, 13-10, but the Chiefs were able to counter with yet another Butker field goal from 47 yards after a 44-yard punt return by Smith.

Denver‚Äôs final drive of the game was the fourth one to last for at least 14 plays, and Nix finished the 65-yard effort with a one-yard touchdown pass to running back RJ Harvey. The key play in the drive was a defensive offside penalty by Chiefs tackle Chris Jones that gave Denver a critical red-zone first down that led to the score.

It‚Äôs remarkable that the Chiefs were even able to give themselves a chance in this one. Oladokun passed for just 66 yards on the night as he went 13-for-22, although he did remain turnover-free. The running game had some moments as the Chiefs were able to pick up some occasional first downs, but Kansas City was simply outgunned in this one due to their quarterback injury issues.

The highlight of the night for the Chiefs was the final drive, which featured some receiving highlights from Kelce, who put Kansas City on his back and nearly win the game single-handed. Kelce was eventually double-teamed, though, and a final pass to receiver Hollywood Brown in the end zone wound up being an overthrow tight as Denver survived.

The Broncos will move on to play the Los Angeles Chargers for the AFC West title next week, assuming the Chargers can beat the Houston Texans on Saturday. That will officially end the Chiefs‚Äô run of division titles at nine, while the Chiefs will close out their broken season against the Las Vegas Raiders in Week 18.

title: Travis Kelce's emotional night at Arrowhead Stadium may be his last with retirement decision looming
description: If Thursday night was the last game Travis Kelce played inside Arrowhead Stadium, he sure tried to make it a memorable one.  The Chiefs tight end only had five catches for 36 yards against Denver, playing alongside third-string quarterback Chris Oladokun while his good buddy Patrick Mahomes and backup Gardner Minshew were out with knee injuries.
fullText:
KANSAS CITY, Mo. (AP) ‚Äî If Thursday night was the last game Travis Kelce played inside Arrowhead Stadium, he sure tried to make it a memorable one.

The Chiefs tight end only had five catches for 36 yards against Denver, playing alongside third-string quarterback Chris Oladokun while his good buddy Patrick Mahomes and backup Gardner Minshew were out with knee injuries. But several of those catches came in the closing minutes, nearly rallying Kansas City in what would have been a stunning upset of the Broncos.

Kelce and Co. wound up losing 20-13 in a game in which they were nearly two-touchdown underdogs.

But it was a gutsy display by him in a career filled with them.

The four-time All-Pro, who is expected to announce soon after the season whether he is retiring, could have hung up the cleats a couple of weeks ago, when the reigning AFC champions were eliminated from playoff contention for the first time in a decade.

Instead, after going to five Super Bowls ‚Äî including the last three ‚Äî and winning three championship rings, the 36-year-old Kelce showed that he had too much pride to quit on a lost season. He played in a humiliating loss to lowly Tennessee last week, and he was one of the few bright spots Thursday night for an offense that finished with 139 yards in all.

‚ÄúA whole lot of emotions,‚Äù Kelce said afterward. ‚ÄúYou've got everybody in the world watching you. You get to go out there with the young guys on primetime television. Young guys getting an opportunity to taste what this NFL life is like.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll let that be a decision I‚Äôll make with my family, friends, the Chiefs organization when the time comes,‚Äù Kelce said.

He was the final player introduced Thursday night, following Oladokun out of the tunnel in the corner of Arrowhead Stadium. As red lights flashed across the field, Kelce emerged from the fog with his signature bow-and-arrow entrance gesture toward a festive holiday crowd, and it predictably roared in delight ‚Äî perhaps for the last time ‚Äî as No. 87 took the field.

‚ÄúYou only get a few of those (moments) where you get to stand there and appreciate 60, 70-thousand Chiefs fans cheering for you,‚Äù Kelce said. ‚ÄúI always embrace that moment.‚Äù

In a suite high above, his fiancee, pop star Taylor Swift, watched him perform. So did Mahomes and Minshew, who took in the game together from a suite; Mahomes tore ligaments in his knee two weeks ago, Minshew did the same last week.

‚ÄúYou feel the generations of happiness and the love that (the fans) have,‚Äù Kelce said. "It‚Äôs a beautiful thing, man. It‚Äôs something I know I‚Äôll cherish forever, whether it‚Äôs coming out of the tunnel or just making a big play for them. That‚Äôs why we love Arrowhead.‚Äù

Kelce has played 97 games inside the stadium over the course of a 13-year career. He caught 645 passes there, including playoffs, the third-most by any player inside a single stadium behind Jerry Rice and Larry Fitzgerald since the AFL-NFL merger.

Now, the question is whether Kelce will play next week in the Chiefs' season finale in Las Vegas.

He needs just 10 yards receiving to reach 13,000 for his career, and he could extend his franchise record ‚Äî and the longest active streak in the NFL ‚Äî by catching a pass in his 191st game next weekend. He could also go out with a win, rather than having lost five straight and seven of his last eight games, which is the slide the Chiefs find themselves on now.

Or, maybe he will surprise everyone and come back for one more year.

‚ÄúWe've been through so much together,‚Äù Chiefs defensive tackle Chris Jones said, making his desire clear. "Just one more (season). Just one more.‚Äù

AP NFL: https://apnews.com/hub/NFL
